etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in John Jamieson (1759–1838), antiquary and philologist. Imitative

definitions: A blow that makes a sound like a rapid, brief movement of air. Compare "biff", "buff".
A resonant barking or grunting sound made by an animal, especially a dog.
A sound made by a rapid, brief movement of air as caused by a sudden move, impact, explosion, etc.
Representing the sound made when expelling breath loudly through the mouth, expressing disgust, disapproval, exertion, etc. Compare "oof".
Representing the sound made by a rapid, brief movement of air as caused by a sudden move, impact, explosion, etc. Compare "bif", "puff".
Representing a resonant barking or grunting sound made by an animal, especially a dog.
